awd_titl_txt: Investigating many-body states of interlayer excitons in 2D atomic double layers
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical: 
Bose-Einstein Condensates are a state of matter predicted by Bose and Einstein nearly a century ago and has been realized in dilute gases of atoms at temperatures close to absolute zero. This discovery has led to tremendous advances in science, precision measurements and quantum information. However, one big hurdle for further technological advances is the extremely low temperature that is required to create these condensates. In this project, the research team develops a new type of Bose-Einstein Condensates formed at high temperatures (>100 K). The artificial atoms are formed in atomically thin membranes of materials that are stacked layer-by-layer. This could result in development of high temperature superconductors and optoelectronic, photonic and quantum devices with unprecedented properties. The project trains graduate and undergraduate students, preparing them as workforce in emerging quantum technologies. The team also develops outreach materials for use in inspiring and broadening participation among young students.

Technical: 
Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) of a dilute gas of atoms occurs at temperatures close to absolute zero. With much smaller mass, excitons (bound electron-hole pairs) are expected to condense at considerably higher temperatures. The emergence of two-dimensional layered semiconductors with very strong exciton binding (about half an electron volt) and flexibility in forming van der Waals heterostructures has opened a new exciting opportunity to explore high-temperature exciton condensate and other emergent quantum many-body ground states. This research project builds on the principal investigator’s prior works and expertise in van der Waals heterostructures and aims to develop new solid-state structures for exciton condensation and exciton condensate-based applications in optoelectronics and photonics. By using optimized design of the double layer structure and an array of experimental probes based on electrical transport and optical measurements, the team aims to achieve three objectives. (i) Search for direct evidence of exciton condensation in transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) double layers such as long-range spatial coherence; (ii) Map the exciton condensation temperature - density phase diagram in the BEC regime and near the BEC to Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer (BCS) crossover; (iii) Search for equilibrium exciton condensates in double layer systems consisting of small gap semiconductors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bosons are particles whose spin quantum number has an integer value. In the ground state, bosons coalesce into a single quantum mechanical entity called Bose-Einstein condensate, which has been experimentally demonstrated for atoms cooled to near absolute zero temperature. Bose-Einstein condensates and other many-body states of bosons are an active research topic in fundamental physics. This project’s primary research focused on developing a solid-state platform to investigate bosons in equilibrium and their many-body states. The bosons of interest are excitons which are bound electron-hole pairs. In contrast to cold atoms, excitons in solids can interact strongly. They can also have a high degeneracy temperature below which the quantum properties of the particles become apparent because high exciton densities can be achieved. The realization of many-body bosonic states in solids may also have implications in electronics, photonics and optoelectronics applications.        

We created structures with two monolayers of semiconductors that are spatially separated by a dielectric spacer of several nanometers in thickness. We placed separate electrical contacts to each semiconductor layer and applied a bias voltage between them. Under a sufficiently large bias voltage, one layer becomes negatively charged (electron-doped), and the other layer, positively charged (hole-doped), but charge tunneling between the two layers remains negligible. The electrons and holes in the two layers interact strongly by the Coulomb force and can form bound pairs (interlayer excitons) with large binding energies.     

We measured the thermodynamic properties of the double layer structure using the capacitance method. We found a new state of matter, excitonic insulator, into which only excitons but not electrons or holes can be injected. The exciton density and the exciton binding energy can be continuously tuned by the bias voltage. We observed exciton fluids with degeneracy temperatures on the order of tens of kelvin. We further performed transport measurements of excitons by passing a current (drive current) in one layer and measuring the induced current (drag current) in the other layer. In the excitonic insulator phase, we observed perfect Coulomb drag, that is, the drag current is equal to the drive current in amplitude but opposite in direction. We also observed large interlayer correlation when the ratio of the electron and hole densities is 1:2 or 2:1. This is a signature of the emergence of trions which are three-particle bound states of electrons and holes.
